Award.AwardTitle: Influence of Electric Field and Stress on Diffusional Sliding at Hetero-Interfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
In most micro/nano-engineered systems, multiple materials are in intimate contact with each other while being subjected to extreme thermal, mechanical and electrical loads. This results in unique scale-sensitive near-interface phenomena, such as diffusional transport along interfaces, driven by a combination of stress, thermal and electric fields. In solid materials, this causes interfacial sliding, which may cause migration of features embedded within a device, causing interfacial strain incompatibilities and potential failure. At liquid-solid interfaces, the application of an electric field can result in movement of the liquid relative to the solid via liquid electromigration (L-EM), which has potential applications in micro-fluidics, conformal coating of circuitry in micro-systems, and tip-based nano-lithography. This proposal has four objectives: (1) obtain mechanistic insight and develop a constitutive model for sliding at solid hetero-interfaces under a combination of stress, electric field and thermal gradient; (2) understand and model diffusional liquid transport at liquid-solid interfaces under a combination of electric field and thermal gradient; (3) correlate the kinetics of diffusion along solid-solid and liquid-solid interfaces to interfacial and near-interface structure and chemistry; and (4) utilize the models and insights generated to simulate the combined impact of shear stress, electromigration and thermomigration on interfacial sliding in solid-solid and liquid-solid systems of practical importance. As such, the insights obtained will be valuable for reliability of micro/nano-electronic devices, as well as for novel applications involving micro/nano-scale liquid-motion, such as tip-based nanolithography and micro-fluidics.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
Micro and nano-scale devices such as those used in electronics have numerous boundaries between disparate materials that are packed very closely together. The materials within these devices are subjected to mechanical, electrical and thermal loads, causing transport of material to occur along the internal boundaries. This can cause severe reliability problems in electronics. Occasionally, when one of the materials undergoes melting due to excessive heating, the same phenomenon also causes flow of the liquid relative to the solid. This presents opportunities to exploit this phenomenon in new technologies like advanced lithography and microfluidics. In the proposed work, mechanistic insight and models for transport along both solid-solid and solid-liquid boundaries will be developed. If successful, the work will have direct impact on the reliability of next-generation electronics, as well as on the development of new manufacturing technologies such as tip-based nanolithography, thus influencing US competitiveness. The project will involve a graduate student and a postdoctoral associate in research and education, undergraduate students through Research Experience for Undergraduates, and outreach to high-school students through a science competition summer program. It will also involve international collaboration with India and collaborative activities with a national laboratory and industry. Results of the project will be broadly disseminated through faculty and student participation at meetings of learned societies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objectives of this research were to: (1) to understand the role of diffusional sliding at hetero-interfaces under a combination of mechanical stress, electric field and thermal gradient; (2) utilize the models and insights generated to study interfacial sliding in selected systems of practical importance (e.g., in microelectronic devices); (3) model interfacial compound growth in very thin layered systems.

        The specific tasks included: (1) developing an analytical constitutive model for interfacial sliding under combined creep, electromigration (EM) and thermomigration (TM) conditions, and conduct MD validation of this model; (2) studying the impact of interfacial sliding in detail on composites comprising micro/nanoscale Cu wires in an In matrix, or Cu through-silicon vias (TSV) in a Si chip, using in situ SEM, scanning white light interferometry and electromigration experiments; (3) conducting experiments on liquid flow on solid substrates under an applied electric field, and assess the impact of substrate roughness; and (4) developing an analytical model for diffusion-limited growth of intermetallic compounds at Cu-Sn interfaces, and validating against experiments.

        Journal papers, book chapters and conference papers were produced based on this work. The team collaborated with Indian Institute of Science on part of the project.  Several seminars were given by the PI at universities and industries on the effects of electromigration, stress migration and thermomigration induced interfacial sliding in electronic devices.

            Graduate students Yang Li, Mahadev Upadhyayula and Benjamin Luce pursued MS thesis work, and one PhD student Yeasir Arafat worked on a variety of experimental techniques including scanning white light interferometry, scanning electron microscopy and atomic force microscopy, and pursued analytical and computational modeling. While an undergraduate student, Benjamin Luce was trained on the use of electrical equipment and building circuitry for electromigration experiments.  A female undergraduate student, Allison Osmanson, learnt sample fabrication, optical microscopy and SEM during the summer of 2016. Postdoctoral associate Lutz Meinshausen was trained a number of experimental techniques, including electroplating, electroless plating, diffusion bonding, thin film deposition, and white light interferometry. Postdoctoral associate Dr. Ming Liu was trained on how to conduct Molecular Dynamics simulations using LAMMPS.  Postdoctoral associate Dr. Hanry Yang was trained on analytical and computational modeling of diffusion-controlled growth of intermetallics at interfaces between bulk metallic substrates and a thin metallic joint.

Images (1 of )
  • A pair of Cu TSV-ends in a Si chip (a), the one on the right being current-carrying. X-ray maps (b-d) showing that the current-carrying TSV is enriched in Sn and Ni due to electromigration-induced diffusion of these elements from materials below the chip.
    Indranath Dutta

    Electromigration induced alloying of copper TSV
  • Ends of a through-silicon via (TSV) in Si, showing evidence of plastic deformation and interfacial sliding during thermal cycling.

Journal papers, book chapters and conference papers were produced based on this work. The team collaborated with Indian Institute of Science on part of the project. Several seminars were given by the PI at universities and industries on the effects of electromigration, stress migration and thermomigration induced interfacial sliding in electronic devices.
